contentrichtext.text: '''Demetrius''' ({{lang-el|Δημήτριος}}; 1st century), a [[Cynicism (philosophy)|Cynic]] [[philosopher]] from [[Corinth]], who lived in [[Rome]] during the reigns of [[Caligula]], [[Nero]] and [[Vespasian]] ([[37 AD|37]]-[[71 AD]]). He was the intimate friend of [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]], who wrote about him often,<ref>Seneca, ''Epistles'', {{ws|''[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 20|20.9]]''}}, {{ws|''[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 62|62.3]]''}}, {{ws|''[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 67|67.14]]''}}, {{ws|''[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 91|91.19]]''}}; ''De Beneficiis'', vii. 1-2, 8-11; ''De Providentia''; ''De Vita Beata''</ref> and who describes him as the perfect man: <blockquote> Demetrius, who seems to have been placed by nature in our times that he might prove that we could neither corrupt him nor be corrected by him; a man of consummate wisdom, though he himself disclaimed it, constant to the principles which he professed, of an eloquence worthy to deal with the mightiest subjects, scorning mere prettinesses and verbal niceties, but expressing with infinite spirit, the ideas which inspired it. I doubt not that he was endowed by divine providence with so pure a life and such power of speech in order that our age might neither be without a model nor a reproach.<ref>Seneca, [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/3794 ''De Beneficiis (On Benefits)''], vii. 8</ref></blockquote> His contempt for worldly riches is shown by his reply to [[Caligula]] who, wishing to corrupt him, offered him two hundred thousand [[sesterces]]. Demetrius replied, "If he meant to tempt me, he ought to have tried to do so by offering his entire kingdom."<ref>Seneca, [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/3794 ''De Beneficiis (On Benefits)''], vii. 11</ref> He was also a friend of [[Publius Clodius Thrasea Paetus|Thrasea Paetus]] and was with him when Thrasea was condemned to death ([[66 AD]]).<ref>Tacitus, [http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/tac/a16030.htm ''Annals'', 16]. 34</ref> We hear of him again in the reign of [[Vespasian]] (c. 70 AD), when, curiously, he defended [[Publius Egnatius Celer]] against the charges brought against him by [[Musonius Rufus]].<ref>Tacitus, [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/16927 ''History''], 4.40</ref> He was exiled from Rome in [[71 AD]], by Vespasian, along with all other philosophers.<ref>Cassius Dio, [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/65*.html ''Roman History, Epitome of Book 65'']</ref> Demetrius is sometimes identified with the Demetrius of [[Sounion|Sunium]] mentioned by [[Lucian]].<ref>Lucian, [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/6829 ''Toxaris''].</ref> However, Demetrius was a very common name in the Roman world, and Demetrius of Sunium was probably, (but not certainly), a different, later Cynic. ==Quotations of Demetrius== *"An easy existence, untroubled by the attacks of Fortune is a Dead Sea"<ref>Seneca, ''Epistles'', {{ws|''[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 67|67.14]]''}}</ref> *"The talk of the ignorant is like the rumblings which issue from the belly."<ref>Seneca, ''Epistles'', {{ws|''[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 91|91.19]]''}}</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{Cynics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Demetrius of Corinth}} [[Category:1st-century Greek people]] [[Category:1st-century philosophers]] [[Category:Roman-era Corinthians]] [[Category:Roman-era Cynic philosophers]] [[Category:Roman-era philosophers in Rome]]
